so I had to do a plug about MQTT that it
is basically becoming I think you know if there is such a thing that the facto standard standard for connected vehicle
messaging there are obviously alternatives and if you think back years ago some of the first solutions we're
all based on UDP but because of the short called shortcomings of UDP they
had to build on top of UDP an entire stack a very chatty stack to ensure
messages are delivered you know I'm sending a message that that's this and then you know unlock the
door and then you send another message back you sent me a message unlock the
door I'm unlocking the door and then you send back another message unlock the door successfully you know you lots of back and forth not quite as
efficient so those are kind of dying away and we're seeing more mqtt orth customers committing to that but again
it's publish and subscribe pub sub really easy it's one-to-many which makes
it easy from the fleet management perspective if I want to push content out to a vehicle or a function I send
one message to the broker and it goes out to everybody there's no polling required for clients
so if you consider that that's a significant savings on power and compute
because you're not polling you know as their messages there are messages they're a message so if you're building
applications that require battery power that's something that's taken to
consider eight consideration and of course there's a very small message overhead with two byte header compare
that to HTTP and then it was designed for sometimes connected networks IBM did
this any Stanford Clark and Ireland nipper invented this I think in 1999 and
they did it for an oil and gas customer to monitor the pipeline's they wanted to
monitor pressure flow rates and temperature to see if there were breaks and the lines and they were doing this
over some very expensive telecom solutions where they had the 80 you know you have to dial into
each of these control units around the whole the whole pipeline to get the status and they're doing this over hard

you can do it with modern programming languages so you're kind of freed from having to write C code that runs on in
an operating system and you think about all the complications and the difficulty with agility that you have in that

down to the vehicle and doing that over the air you can do that to one vehicle or you can do it to a fleet of vehicles

efficient way to get business function there the second really interesting thing is around machine learning
